title-group.article-title: Early Rescue of Interneuron Disease Trajectory in Developmental Epilepsies

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Molecular and Human Genetics, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX 77030, USA
2Department of Neurology, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX 77030, USA
3Department of Neuroscience, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX 77030, USA

abstract.p: The discovery of over 150 monogenic epilepsies and advances in early genetic diagnoses have launched a search for molecular strategies and developmental timetables to reverse or even prevent the course of these debilitating brain disorders. Orthologous rodent models of key disease genes are providing important examples of the range of targets, and serve as valuable test systems for perinatal therapeutic approaches. While gene-specific analyses of single rare ‘orphan’ diseases are each narrow in scope, they illuminate downstream pathways converging onto interneurons, and treatments that strengthen inhibition during cortical maturation may provide broad protection against these seemingly disparate gene errors. Several genes, even those linked to malformations, show promise for postnatal correction before the onset of their clinical phenotype.
